comments.commentBody:
Not exactly. #1, #2, #3 came from the mortgage brokers and fake-it-all mortgage banking operations.

#4 came from standard banks, which served as fences for the mortgage broker burglars.

#5 and #6 came from the sociopathic Wall St. crowd, you betcha.

Google [ florence cioffi anderson ceo dui ] if you want to see what the Wall St. crew learned to think about criminal law. Basically, in Manhattan, they own it. If you can kill people, why should bribery and fraud cause a bother?

Don't forget the US government. They deregulated much of the industry, and in doing so made this all possible. Fannie and Freddie never even had to meet the minimum regs that the banks did.

And don't forget Clinton's insistence that everyone had a right to own a home. He was/is wrong, of course. You have no right to own a home when you cannot afford to pay for it. But, it seems we all forget how this whole thing really started.

You can rail against Wall Street, banks, and mortgage lenders, but without the legislative changes and push from DC to Freddie, Fannie, Ginny, and the VHA loan systems, this would never have happened.
Yes, the "Friendly sociopathic bankers" did it but they did it with the help of the "Friendly sociopathtic lawyers", and it's also why none of them are in prison.

Who invented no-documentation mortgages ?

Who invented no-money-down mortgages ?

Who invented teaser rate mortgages ?

Who demanded an ever increasing number of of these cockeyed mortgages in order to slice and dice them and dump them off on investors as AAA securities ?

Who paid the rating agencies to rate these junk securities as AAA ?

Who built this fraud from the ground up all the way to the national and international stock exchanges, pension plans and 401Ks of citizens around the globe.

Your friendly, sociopathic Wall St. investment-bankster, that's who.

The criminal class on Wall St. remain the greatest thieves and threats to national security America has ever had.

The history of house prices is very interesting.  Prior to WW II house prices depreciated as with any other consumable.  Only after the war, with the baby boom, did housing suddenly become viewed as an investment.  Homes should be equated with rental apartments, not stocks and bonds.  The only reason why houses should ever appreciate is pure supply and demand in an otherwise unaffected Market.  Clearly when Big Daddy in DC decided that "everyone should have their own home" as though it were in the Constitution did this huge Ponzi scheme begin.  The pols then hit up banks to make ridiculous loans to folks who had zero capacity to pay their mortgages.  The builders didn't care as long as they moved houses.  The banks simply folded lousy loans into "marketable" securities that the rating agencies (with amazing alacrity) handed high ratings upon.  Having any government interference in any economic activity is a complete and utter disaster.  We witnessed the housing bubble and are about to be whopped by Obama Care, a program which will cost trillions more than estimated and come quite close to bankrupting the US.

As a woman, I thought it was terribly romantic of me to agree to become engaged without a ring of any kind.  In fact, it was my idea -- I guess to prove that I loved him no matter what.  Forty-one years later, we're still married, but I've been kicking myself just about that long.

Nothing to do with today or yesterday, since this has been going on for decades. And it's not about passing judging on a 17 year old at all.  It's about an artificially limited construct of merchandising culture that people seem to have swallowed hook, line, and sinker. The whole diamond ring thing is so limiting and so corseted in terms of how it lines people up in a hierarchy of how much is spent and not much else. Even in a material world, if one person buys a nice coat for someone, another a ruby, another a gold band, another a nice vacation, another a wonderful pair of shoes, they all are allowed dignity, and we can all appreciate and respect everyone's efforts to do something nice for another, a sacrifice or expression of love. But when it's all lined up on the size of a diamond, then it's just about money, plain and simple and those who have the larger rock can lord it over others and make them envious. Ultimately, as a whole, this isn't imaginative, expressive, profoundly human, or good for either the person gloating or the envious. It's only good for De Beers, the blood diamond profiteers, and the jewelry merchants.
a very true and honest ending.  Sometimes it isn't parents that cause a break-up, and we can only see that when we are far out from under their influence and own our mistakes.  Great story.

Not all dogs that show aggression/protective behavior in certain situations are bad...

Family dog helps alert parents to abusive baby sitter

http://news.yahoo.com/dog-helps-alert-parents-to-abusive-babysitter-1643...

I grew up in my grandfather's house; he was a Talmudic scholar. I am a product of the Lower East Side, and the Borscht Belt.

The rabbis of the Talmud considered marriage a holy contract, and the dissolution of marriage an unholy act. They quote the prophet Malachi, “. . the Lord has been witness between you and your wife of your youth against whom you have dealt treachorously, though she is your companion, the wife of your covenant” (2:14). Jewish Oral Law added in Sanhedrin (22a), “Even G-d shares tears when anyone divorces his wife.”

Borscht Belt wisdom: Dog backwards spells god. There's a reason.

"Does the Times have a farm upstate where they breed these people?"

In Buffalo.
While what you say is probably true, don't beat yourself up too much - Chocolates are awfully intense all on their own.

I've fostered several rescue dogs where neglect and physical abuse were very apparent-- malnourished, abandoned on a chain in a yard, covered in tar, beaten, etc). They don't belong in just any home because little billy or little princess wanted a cute dog. That's how a lot of them end up in the shelters or rescues. (and "many" doesn't imply "most.")

I'd got for the rescue over the breeder dog anyday.
Get 'em spayed and neutered while you're at it. :)

Medstudent, that WOULD be unfair, but that wasn't the case. The Lab was always with my parents - I was in high school when we got her. The rescue was adopted a number of years later, as a puppy. I happened to move back home some time after his negative behaviors had begun to appear, after my folks had started working with a trainer. He became my project while I was underemployed, applying to grad schools, and living at home. It eventually became clear that even with a wonderful trainer (the professional) and a dedicated human (me), it was unsustainable and unfair to the Lab to keep them in the same home. There was a very painful, frightening period of uncertainty while we got the rescue out of the house but were never quite ready to give up on him. But the story is a happy one now (I won't say "ending"). Lab is 14, aging but still as happy and loving as ever, in the only home she's ever known (other than birth, I suppose). And my Mix-now 5-is asleep next to my bed; he's lying on his back, which is a sign of such relaxation that I had never seen him do it until last year, but he now does all the time. And only when we're alone-even in his sleep, his anxieties still grow and fade with his surroundings.

You were right to be indignant to what you thought was disrespect. I'm sorry if I was unclear; rest assured that both dogs are happy and in their rightful homes.

could not have said it better.

there is plenty of good information on THE INTERNET, and that has been around for at least 1000 years. a LIBRARY came some time before the 'net; they contain books filled with excellent information and dust-caked jackie collins novels.

i think the author is brave for relating her tail of abject failure.
really, this "owner" failed Chance from the outset by never dealing with what appears to be his first bout with fear, which the owner's inattentiveness is entirely to blame. but instead of accepting responsibility, she gives excuses.

i hope to god(tm) she doesn't have kids--she's already shown she couldn't take care of them.

I have a "dumped dog" that I found as a 4-month old, running loose in a grocery-store parking lot in the rain 10 years ago. Halle was not socialized at all, and it was a year before she realized that sitting still for three minutes to have her ears scratched was enjoyable. One day, while we were out walking, a little "yip dog" (Halle now weighs 70 pounds) came running out of its yard, yapping at us. Halle, leashed, growled it. This dog had bothered me many times before, especially when I was out running. The owners may have thought it wasn't big enough to be a problem, but a good bite in my calf IS a problem, and if Halle had decided to have that dog for dessert, I was the one who was going to get sued. I tied Halle to a signpost across the street and knocked on the owners' door. I explained extremely firmly, but calmly, that letting their dog run loose was against the law, and if I found it loose again, I would call animal control. (I learned my "explaining" technique in the Army.) I think I scared them, which made me feel bad, sort of, but small dogs can be as dangerous as large ones if the mix is right. I don't think their owners understand that.
Well, aren't we snide and judgemental? Is the Torah's wisdom on divorce pertinent here?

Snarky, I know, but one wonders if the extremely ex first husband had as much slack cut for him as the poorly behaved dog.

Most people mellow as they get older.

Give her a break people! Her article is a reminder to be' In the Moment' and being 'Mindful' with people and animals you love and care deeply for.
Its not about being a privileged white girl or getting a dog from the shelter. We all make mistakes in our lives and we have to say sorry to people/animals we have hurt and this is her way of saying sorry to her beloved Bad/Good dog.
Love your article Rachel and I deeply sorry for your pain. Blessings!
yes, it was a dark & stormy night...
As George Carlin said, "life is a series of dogs."
Skateboarders and rollerbladers - my dog goes ballistic every single time.

Most people are inadvertently rewarding their dogs bad behavior - example - walking dog down the street, and when another dog on leash approaches the owner lets their dog go ballistic, and is rewarded when the other dog goes away. Same concept with the mailman at the door. Dog is reacting from fear. The dog will keep repeating this behavior unless you teach them otherwise. Reinforce good behavior by teaching your dog to sit and stay and using treats. You can do this with anything your dog reacts to, just need to start far enough away and decrease the distance gradually. I got my dog at the shelter 4 years ago and she had no idea how to walk on a leash. Things are much better now...still working on the reaction to skateboarders though.
How did you come to this conclusion from an article about a person's love for their dog?  All of us and our dogs are to an extent dysfunctional - that's what life is...

Housing is an investment not a consumable. It retains value and is not consumed by use. Housing is the single largest investment of most Americans. Falling house prices have a negative wealth effect that is worse than falling stock prices. It would be as bad if housing prices fell everywhere as if stock prices fell everywhere.

James.. you are so angry.. I'm sorry you feel that you must demean this talented author who has actually opened up and written something beautiful that brought tears to my eyes.

I hope someday you realize that we are all the same. Rich, Poor... It doesn't matter. Who cares if she is privileged. If you feel such disdain for people go read the Daily News.

I have a similar story with my dog Pace whom I rescued when he was one (or so). He was aggressive with other dogs,and it made it difficult for me to exercise him off leash (a catch-22). We went to the local humane society classes, but her training style did not work with him. The trainer was against the training style I had previously used with a dog I rescued at 4 months old (and let me know it!).  Not until years later did I finally allow myself to find a great trainer who used a more aggressive training style (with no apologies) that did work with him. Moral of the story: Don't wait. Find a trainer that works.
All Dogs Go To Heaven.
It wouldn't be heaven if there weren't dogs there.

I read these stories and am no longer surprised at how eerily similar to my experiences with my rescue dog Ariki (aka Nuppy). Eerily!

I realize the following, among other things, my dog/bff is special, and more special to me than to anyone else. Although he makes friends instantly and treats every human he meets like a long lost friend. I think this is mutual.

Having said that, dogs in general are amazing creatures, angels if you will indulge me. They bring out things in us that need to come out, good things!!

Dogs teach us is ways we can't imagine, appreciate, or even realize at the time. I think to myself, the world would be so great if everyone was required to own and care for at least one dog in his or her life.

I have a coaster that says "Let me be the person my dog thinks I am", true dat!

I fear the day that I pen the story of my dog's last days, and the emotions associated with that. Until then, I will appreciate every minute (seven minutes to Ariki) that we share together.

I sure hope dogs do go to heaven!! Well, depends on where I end up I suppose.

Cheers!

I also owned a not so good dog.  He was territorial.  A great watch dog.  Not overly friendly with new people. Suspicious of children (except the one he lived with--something to herd!).  A humper.  I could go on and on.  When he was a young adult, he was most definitively a bad dog.  But he was my bad dog.  He's been gone for 5 years now.  I'm still not over it.  I kind of miss saying, "What have you done now?!"  I always enjoying reading dog stories.  Thanks for the smile.
